g.text: Regularization in Directable Environments with Application to Tetris

EW has a long history of use in the social sciences. It ap-
peared in a seminal paper by
could outperform human expert judgements. The article
also demonstrated that EW can compete well with OLS
on real-world data sets, stimulating further work on equal-
weighting models in the 1970s, continuing to this day (
weighting models have also been found to be useful in other
types of problems, including paired comparison (
deﬁned as the sign of the corresponding weight, which
can be positive or negative. An environment is said to be
if the directions of the features are known. In a
directable environment, features can be “directed” so that
the weights are all positive (for example, by recoding any
feature with a negative weight by multiplying its values
Weight estimates, as a function of the regularization
data set with seven standardized features.
). Many problems are naturally constrained to have
only positive weights (for example mixing problems, see
problems, features can be directed intuitively by the user,
knowledge, directions can be estimated from relatively few
Notice that EWis a sensible model only if the features are
directed so that the true weights have identical signs. The
rationale for the use of EW in psychology and decision
making is the assumption that people are good in choos-
ing relevant features and know—through intuition or past
The model we propose, STEW, can also use this knowledge
Motivated by the surprisingly high performance of equal-
weighting models in the literature—not only in regression
but also in classiﬁcation, paired comparison, and portfolio
optimization—we propose to use the equal-weights model
as a prior in regularization. In other words, we make the
features have equal impact on the re-
. This assumption leads to the regularization
differences in the magnitude of the weights. It leaves the
choice of feature directions free. However, the differences
of absolute values within the penalty function make the loss
function difﬁcult to optimize. We therefore use a penalty
function that assumes a directable environment.
